fields.label_text:
'Flowers of the Fields of France' ceremonial gown
Norman Hartnell (1901-79)
London
1957

Hartnell, who had been court dressmaker since 1938, designed this dress for the Queen's state visit to Paris. The embroidery, with poppies, fleurs-de-lis, wheat sheaves and bees (Napoleon's symbol of industry) was designed to compliment the host nation. One of the embroiderers said, 'We just hoped that she always sat on plush chairs so it did not get squashed!' 

Duchesse satin, pearls, beads, brilliants, faceted glass, with mother-of-pearl and gold thread

Worn by Her Majesty The Queen for the state visit to Paris, April 1957
V&A: T.264-1974

fields.descriptive_line: State evening dress of embroidered duchesse satin, designed by Norman Hartnell, London, spring/summer 1957.

fields.name: Fashion: an anthology by Cecil Beaton
The Golden Age of Couture. Paris and London 1947 - 1957
The Cutting Edge: 50 Years of British Fashion
French Connections: Memories of Her Majesty The Queen In Paris

fields.physical_description:
Stated full skirted evening dress of ivory silk satin. It consists of a princess seamed bodice with draped fold at hips, which extends into a large self-fabric bow. It is embroidered with pearls, beads, brilliants and gold thread.

The dress is richly embroidered with miniature bees, grasses, wheat and wild flowers worked in relief in faceted glass stones, gold beads, brilliants and variously shaped pearls, with mother-of-pearl and cloth of gold petals.
fields.title: The Flowers of the Fields of France
fields.materials_techniques: Duchesse satin, embroidered with pearls, beads, brilliants, and gold thread
fields.label:
'Flowers of the Fields of France' ceremonial gown
Norman Hartnell (1901-79)
London
1957

Hartnell, who had been court dressmaker since 1938, designed this dress for the Queen's state visit to Paris. The embroidery, with poppies, fleurs-de-lis, wheat sheaves and bees (Napoleon's symbol of industry) was designed to compliment the host nation. One of the embroiderers said, 'We just hoped that she always sat on plush chairs so it did not get squashed!' 

Duchesse satin, pearls, beads, brilliants, faceted glass, with mother-of-pearl and gold thread

Worn by Her Majesty The Queen for the state visit to Paris, April 1957
V&A: T.264-1974 [22/09/2007-06/01/2008]
fields.public_access_description: Lavish gold and white beadwork encrusts this ivory evening dress worn by Queen Elizabeth II on a state visit to Paris in 1957. The dazzling, jewel-like details of the embroidered design include miniature bees, grasses, wheat and wild flowers. These motifs are worked in relief in faceted glass, gold beads, brilliants and variously shaped pearls, mother-of-pearl and gold petals. It also features an extravagant back bow. The design of this single-occasion gown diplomatically refers to French motifs, including the flowers of France and large gold bees, the emblem of Napoleon. It was intended to both compliment the French nation and draw attention to the Queen.

fields.bibliography: de la Haye, Amy, ed. The Cutting Edge: 50 Years of British Fashion 1947-1997. V&A Publications, London, 1997, pp. 64 and 65. Vickers, H., 'Cecil Beaton' in Wilcox, C., ed., The Golden Age of Couture: Paris and London 1947-57 (V&A Publications, London), p.165 & pl.7.9. Her Majesty The Queen donated a 1965 Hardy Amies day ensemble and, to avoid causing ruptures in the world of couture, the Norman Hartnell dress from the April 1957 state visit to Paris, at which Beaton had been a guest. (pl.7.8). He had been invited by Lady Jebb (later Lady Gladwyn), wife of the British Ambassador in Paris, to sketch the return state banquet at which the queen had entertained president René Coty at the British Embassy in Paris. At the time, he had written to his hostess, saying 'The Queen triumphed over Hartnell's bad taste'. Despite this, he was delighted to accept the ivory satin evening dress, encrusted with beads, brilliants and gold. Beaton succeeded in acquiring several other dresses worn during the same visit. Lady Gladwyn donated the lilac lace evening dress [T.173-1974] by French designer, Jacques Fath. Lady Diana Cooper, Lady Gladwyn's (and Beaton's) great friend, donated a strapless Balmain gown of appliqué printed silk satin [T.50-1974]. Baroness Alain de Rothschild (Mary Chauvin de Treuil), the wife of one of the Rothschild banking brothers, gave a white spotted tulle dress by Dior [T.121-1974] (all pl.7.9). Jebb, M., ed. The Diaries of Cynthia Gladwyn (London, 1995), pp.205-13 Frankly her clothes – though praised tremendously in the English papers with such remarks as ‘Paris gasped’ or ‘The Queen in her Hartnell dress stole the show’ (a silly remark, because she in fact was the show) – were not very beautiful, and did not compare with the French clothes. Cecil Beaton wrote to me afterwards; ‘The Queen triumphed over Hartnell’s bad taste’. p.208 The Royalist, Friday, 29 September 2006 'Memories of life as the Queen's seamstress' by Joanne Leyland She's worked on outfits for some of the world's most famous faces, from the Queen to soccer star David Beckham. Now an embroideress has let the world into her memories of working for one of the world's most celebrated fashion houses as a new exhibition of some of the most stunning items from the Queen's wardrobe opens at Kensington Palace. Visitors to the new Palace exhibition have been treated to a one-off demonstration of embroiderer Marureen Markham's skills, following which she spoke about her memories of a life which has seen her work on some of the Queen's most famous gowns. When Her Majesty visited the Paris Opera House during a state visit to France in 1957, even the most hardened republicans were won over by her style as the young Queen made her entrance in an ivory floor-length gown which incorporated Napoleonic bees, French emblems and hundreds of meticulously embroidered beads, pearls and gold thread. The Norman Hartnell dress was such a hit it was even awarded its own name: the Flower of the Fields of France evening gown. Recalls the 67-year-old needlewoman, who worked for Hartnell for 26 years: "I met the Queen several times. Whenever she had a fitting of one of our dresses, the boss would take me along. She was always very charming and when this particular dress was made, she was tiny." "All Norman Hartnell designs are very elaborate and intricate. I must have spent about three weeks embroidering this one, working on it for seven hours a day. It could be quite fiddly work but I loved it. It's nice to be creative and to see the results of your work." Miss Markham also worked on the wardrobes of other royals, including Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother and the most glamorous Princess of the pre-Diana generation, the film star-esque Princess Margaret. Despite the sudden death of Norman Hartnell in the 1970s, Markham continued to have an impact on the royal wardrobe, working as she did for the Queen's new designer, Ian Thomas. Although now semi-retired, the embroideress is still contracted to undertake work on behalf of Buckingham Palace. Clearly, though, it will be hard to top those starry-eyed days when the eyes of the world were on the dresses which were truly fit for a Queen. The new royal exhibition, French Connections: Memories of Her Majesty The Queen In Paris, at which the Flower of the Fields of France dress is a star attraction, can be seen at Kensington Palace from now until March 18th 2007. The Queen wearing T.264-1974. Photo by Central Press/Getty Images. Image #: 3362039 Queen's Speech Caption: 'April 1957: The Queen gives a speech at a banquet at The Elysée Palace in Paris. To the right of her is French President, René Coty (1882 - 1962).' The Queen wearing T.264-1974. Photo by Popperfoto/Getty Images. Image #: 78961829 Caption: 'April 1957. Paris, France. HM.Queen Elizabeth II pictured with French President René Coty while on her official visit to France.' Picture Post, April 1957 (Special 80 page supplement) Pictures and text - 'The dress only the Queen could wear'. Life magazine, April 22, 1957 Article entitled: Paris and Queen Elizabeth II glitter for each other Picture Post #8890, April 1957 (see also Getty Images ref 50995973; Photo by Bert Hardy/Picture Post/Getty Images) Article - 'The Queen Conquers France'
fields.credit: Given by Her Majesty the Queen
fields.history_note: This splendid state gown with an extravagant back bow was designed for the Queen's state visit to Paris, April 8-11th 1957. The design diplomatically makes reference to French motifs, including the "Flowers of the Fields of France" (such as daisies and crossed wheat sheaves) and Napoleonic bees. It was worn to the state dinner on the first night (Monday 8th April), hosted by President René Coty at the Elysée Palace, followed by a visit to the Opéra to see a ballet by Lifar from The Diaries of Cynthia Jebb. The dress was worn with a necklace (of 4 stones with centre drop jewel) and small earrings, a tiara, and long white evening gloves adorned with a bracelet (or small watch) on the left wrist. The Queen also wore the jewelled Badge of the Legion d'Honneur and sash from her right shoulder to her waist (left). She also carried a small white handbag and wore a white fur stole for travelling. The dress was displayed at Kensington Palace in 2006-7. Research conducted by Kensington Palace included an interview with Maureen Markham, one of the embroiderers who worked on the dress. She recalled that they worked with blacked-out windows to avoid the Press and that she hoped the Queen would have nice plush cushions to sit on so as not to crush the embroidery. The Queen wore this dress again to the Opera in the early 1960s. Historical significance: The 1957 State Visit followed the Treaty of Rome, which created the European Economic Community (EEC).
fields.production_note: Designed for the Queen's state visit to Paris in April 1957.
fields.historical_context_note: The Museum of Civilization, Canada, has a dress designed by Norman Hartnell for the Queen's state visit to Canada in the same year, 1957.  It is known as the 'Maple Leaf of Canada dress', and has a beautiful garland of maple leaves mingled with white roses (the emblem of the House of York). Each leaf is made of green velvet appliquéd with crystal and imitation emeralds. The white roses are formed with crystals, imitation white pearls, and imitation diamonds.  The Queen wore the dress at the state banquet and reception at Rideau Hall, the Governor General's official residence, on October 14, 1957.
